intro: Androsace raddeana, commonly known as the alpine bellflower, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Asia. It belongs to the Primulaceae family and is characterized by its rosette of hairy, spoon-shaped leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that are typically white or pale pink, blooming in early summer. It thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky habitats. Due to its delicate appearance and unique growth habits, it is a popular subject in botanical studies and garden cultivation.
